variants: Yeah… I guess that’s true.

factual.opener: If you know something, just say it. Everyone's in the dark, but the facts are out there.
variants: Halden was found dead. That's no secret now.
Authorities gave almost nothing in their announcement.
No one is saying why he died or who takes over.
System outages started the same day, nothing explained.
That's the basic story.

When Halden died, it threw every part of the system out of sync.
Whole buildings lost key access—no overridings worked. Even our lab felt it.
The official line is just bland, but there were medical reports that went private fast.
He was last seen entering Tower 9. After that—nothing until they found him.
Everyone up the chain's acting like it's business as usual, but it's not.
The day before Halden's death, he missed a critical review, just vanished from routine.
Security footage only caught him going into his office—Tower 9—and that's the last trace.
Lab chatter says his toxicology report showed sedatives, but medical records got locked before anyone could confirm it.
No investigation, even though system logs flagged tons of user inconsistencies that day.
I've seen archived data get wiped lately—whole profiles vanish. We can't even audit what's missing.
Before Halden died, he'd started pulling all system data into his control—enforcement, everything. It shut out our own teams.
There were arguments in the Council last year, especially over predictive scoring—it got so bad they let him move funds around solo.
That morning, our internal logs flagged his credentials as failing. I've never seen core access like that just drop out.
Sedatives were found in his system, but the medical file's sealed. The Directorate's internal health unit blocked any criminal inquiry.
The same week, several of us noticed hundreds of flagged names gone from watchlists. Like they were deleted, not just archived.
Whatever happened, someone in the upper Council is hiding it, and the system failures aren't just tech problems—they're gaps they don't want to explain.
Honestly, after what happened to my brother during a BCI audit, I keep everything triple-encrypted now. Can't trust the system or the people running it.
